awd_titl_txt: Phase I IUCRC University of South Alabama: Center for Advanced Research in Forensic Science (CARFS)
awd_abstract_narration:
In recent decades, a rapid transition from fundamental discoveries to forensic method development has improved the quality of evidence in many types of forensic investigations. However, there has also been a call, at the national level, for forensic disciplines to address their scientific limitations and expand fundamental research that can underpin and improve existing and developing forensic applications.  Investigators at the University of South Alabama (USA) and Florida International University (FIU), along with affiliated collaborators at Texas A&M University (TAMU), the University of North Texas Health Science Center (UNTHSC), Northeastern University (NE), and George Washington University (GWU), will address aspects of this broad challenge through the formation of the Center for Advanced Research in Forensic Science (CARFS). This Industry University Cooperative Research Center (IUCRC) will serve as a platform for innovative and, in many cases, interdisciplinary forensic science research activities at the interface of academia, government, and industry. CARFS will initially include digital forensics/data analytics (USA), forensic chemistry (FIU/NE/GWU), forensic molecular biology (FIU/GWU), and forensic microbiology (TAMU/UNT), with the possibility of future expansion to include other forensic disciplines. The Center is anticipated to provide new findings and tools to a range of stakeholders, including forensic science practitioners, research laboratories, industrial partners, and government and private forensic science end users, and will ultimately support safety and justice for the nation. The Center's research sites will also provide training opportunities to a diverse group of students, thus supporting the pipeline of future forensic researchers.

As part of CARFS, the USA site, including affiliates at TAMU and UNTHSC, will focus on digital and microbial forensics. At USA, research will focus on Digital Forensic Information Intelligence, including the development, testing, and implementation of novel approaches to understand not only how devices, information systems, and software can be compromised, but also how one can reliably determine how those compromises occurred. The research will support the development of new technologies with potentially cross cutting industry impact: (1) mobile devices, (2) additive manufacturing, (3) medical devices, (4) transportation systems, as well as (5) generation and storage of large scale data sets (forensic microbiology). At TAMU and UNTHSC, research will focus on forensically important phenomena of decomposition and ecological recycling of vertebrate carrion, to support human identification and source attribution; taphonomy; counterterrorism/drug interdiction; and validation services. The research will address scientific challenges in forensics as well as applications in broader areas of human importance (e.g., food safety, engineering, structural integrity, agriculture). Across the six institutions involved in CARFS there is also potential for innovative projects that span and integrate digital and laboratory sciences.

This grant is jointly supported by NSF (Division of Chemistry, Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate; and Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences, Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Directorate) and the National Institute of Justice (Office of Investigative and Forensic Sciences).
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Cloud Stack Analysis via Performance Metrics, Part II

Results

This research demonstrated that machine learning models can be used to distinguish workloads running on a containerized system based on performance measures collected while each workload was running. Machine learning used to train models that recognize the regular performance patterns of performance metrics on workloads running in a containerized cloud stack environment could be a solution the problem of conducting forensics investigations on cloud stack environments. In addition to distinguishing workloads, we were able to narrow the number of metrics down to a relatively small subset of significant metrics for distinguishing workloads. While the specific metrics that were deemed useful in our analysis may not be useful on all environments or workloads, it could be possible to narrow metrics down to a small subset for all environments. Modeling of the performance measures of normal behavior could be used to monitor workloads on containerized systems that could then be used to recognize anomalous behavior in forensics investigations and in active monitoring. The anomalous behavior could be the result of malicious activity or benign yet abnormal behavior. The ability to detect the presence anomalous behavior in containerized environments can aid forensics investigators in understanding conditions leading up to an undesirable situation. In addition to forensic analysis, machine learning techniques could aid system operators to effectively recognize and intervene in the presence of unexpected behavior occurs.

Transformer networks-based malware classification for Android-based attacks, Part II

Results

In terms of the machine learning classifiers, we discovered our ability to detect repackaged versus repackaged was very poor.  All the classifiers, with the exception of Naïve Bayes, could correctly identify 3% of the original at best; they also predicted repackaged at rates ranging from 67.3% to 100%.  Naïve Bayes had a rate of 35.5% detection for the original but also had a 33.3% at detecting repackaged.  We tried reducing the number of repackaged examples to see if this was leading to a distortion.  However, this did not change the overall success rate.  We also looked at changing the “width” of the images; again, this had no impacts.

With respect to the CNN model, we also had poor results; it was no better than guessing random.  When used on malware/non-malware data, we achieved an accuracy of 90%, which means the code was working (and confirmed results achieved in part 1 of the study).  BERT models also did equally poorly for normal versus repackaged.  However, RNN had better results than random, but not much better. 

In all, we think the problem may be with the data.  Based on past experience, we know some problems require more data in order for the learning methods to find patterns.  In addition, some papers we have found indicate that different repackaging programs may leave different signatures; the papers were from over 10 years ago and we know the technology changed.  Hence, we recommend acquiring a large number of applications, and then use a known repackaging tool to repackage the normal applications.  This would (a) ensure we are using current technology and (b) remove any variations that may occur due to differences in repackaging software.

 


Last Modified: 10/15/2024
Modified by: Michael Chambers
